name: Norway
description: Norway is not an EU member but participates in the European Economic Area (EEA), adopting EU data protection regulations including GDPR. Norwegian companies and data centers offer strong sovereignty for organizations seeking to avoid non-European jurisdiction.

national_laws.name: Personopplysningsloven
national_laws.full_name: Lov om behandling av personopplysninger (Personal Data Act)
national_laws.summary: Norwegian implementation of GDPR. Regulates processing of personal data and establishes Datatilsynet as the supervisory authority.

national_laws.name: Ekomloven
national_laws.full_name: Lov om elektronisk kommunikasjon (Electronic Communications Act)
national_laws.summary: Regulates electronic communications networks and services, including data retention and lawful interception requirements.

national_laws.name: Sikkerhetsloven
national_laws.full_name: Lov om nasjonal sikkerhet (National Security Act)
national_laws.summary: Protects national security interests, including requirements for security clearances and protection of sensitive information.

name: Sweden
description: Sweden is an EU member state with strong data protection traditions. Home to several major data centers and tech companies operating under EU law.

name: Denmark
description: Denmark is an EU member state with robust digital infrastructure and data protection aligned with GDPR.

name: Finland
description: Finland is an EU member state known for transparency and strong rule of law. Popular location for data centers due to cold climate and renewable energy.

name: Germany
description: Germany has some of the strictest data protection interpretations in the EU. German Datenschutz (data protection) culture runs deep, with strong enforcement by state-level authorities.

national_laws.name: BDSG
national_laws.summary: German federal data protection law supplementing GDPR with additional national requirements.

name: France
description: France is an EU member with the CNIL as one of Europe's most active data protection authorities. France has been pushing for European digital sovereignty.

name: Netherlands
description: Netherlands hosts major internet exchanges and data centers. EU member with strong tech sector and data protection traditions.

name: Poland
description: Poland is an EU member state with growing data center infrastructure.

name: Ireland
description: Ireland hosts European headquarters for many US tech giants (Google, Meta, Microsoft). The Irish DPC is the lead supervisory authority for many cross-border cases, though criticized for slow enforcement.

name: Austria
description: Austria is an EU member known for privacy activism. The Schrems cases that invalidated Safe Harbor and Privacy Shield originated from Austrian privacy advocate Max Schrems.

name: Switzerland
description: Switzerland is not an EU/EEA member but has an EU adequacy decision. Known for banking secrecy and neutrality, with strong data protection under the revised FADP.

national_laws.name: FADP
national_laws.summary: Swiss data protection law revised in 2023 to align more closely with GDPR while maintaining Swiss specifics.

name: USA
description: The United States has broad surveillance laws that grant government access to data held by US companies, regardless of where the data is stored. The CLOUD Act is particularly concerning for European organizations using US cloud providers.

national_laws.name: CLOUD Act
national_laws.full_name: Clarifying Lawful Overseas Use of Data Act
national_laws.summary: US can compel US companies to hand over data regardless of where it is stored. This extraterritorial reach is a key concern for data sovereignty.

national_laws.name: FISA Section 702
national_laws.summary: Allows surveillance of non-US persons located outside the US for foreign intelligence purposes. EU citizens have limited legal protections.

national_laws.name: Patriot Act
national_laws.full_name: Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act
national_laws.summary: Broad access to records for national security investigations, including Section 215 bulk data collection.

national_laws.name: ECPA
national_laws.summary: Government access to electronic communications and stored data with various warrant requirements.

name: United Kingdom
description: Post-Brexit, the UK has an EU adequacy decision but maintains broad surveillance powers under the Investigatory Powers Act. A Five Eyes member with extensive intelligence-sharing arrangements.

national_laws.name: Investigatory Powers Act
national_laws.summary: Broad surveillance powers including bulk data collection, equipment interference, and communications interception. Requires ISPs to retain browsing history.

national_laws.name: National Security Act
national_laws.summary: Powers to address foreign interference, espionage and state threats.

national_laws.name: UK GDPR
national_laws.summary: Post-Brexit version of GDPR retained in UK law, providing similar protections to EU GDPR.

name: China
description: China requires organizations and citizens to cooperate with national intelligence work. Data localization requirements and strict cross-border transfer rules make it difficult to use Chinese services while maintaining data sovereignty.

national_laws.name: National Intelligence Law
national_laws.full_name: National Intelligence Law of the People's Republic of China
national_laws.summary: Organizations and citizens must support, assist and cooperate with national intelligence work. This creates backdoor access concerns for any Chinese software.

national_laws.name: Cybersecurity Law
national_laws.full_name: Cybersecurity Law of the People's Republic of China
national_laws.summary: Data localization requirements, security reviews, and network operator obligations for critical infrastructure.

national_laws.name: Data Security Law
national_laws.full_name: Data Security Law of the People's Republic of China
national_laws.summary: Data classification system, cross-border transfer restrictions, and government access for national security.

national_laws.name: PIPL
national_laws.summary: China's comprehensive personal data protection law with strict cross-border transfer requirements.

name: Russia
description: Russia is subject to international sanctions following the 2022 invasion of Ukraine. Data localization laws require Russian citizen data to be stored in Russia, and SORM requires surveillance backdoors.

national_laws.name: Yarovaya Law
national_laws.summary: Mandatory data retention for 6 months, decryption assistance requirements for authorities.

national_laws.name: Data Localization Law
national_laws.full_name: Federal Law No. 242-FZ on Personal Data Localization
national_laws.summary: Personal data of Russian citizens must be stored on servers physically located in Russia.

national_laws.name: SORM
national_laws.summary: Mandatory surveillance backdoors in all telecommunications equipment for FSB access.

name: Israel
description: Israel has an EU adequacy decision for certain sectors. Known for advanced cybersecurity industry but also surveillance technology exports.

name: India
description: India has broad government surveillance powers under the IT Act. The new DPDP Act provides some protection but with significant government exemptions.

national_laws.name: IT Act
national_laws.summary: Government can intercept, monitor and decrypt any computer resource in the interest of national security.

national_laws.name: DPDP Act
national_laws.summary: Personal data protection with broad government exemptions for national security.

name: Australia
description: Australia is a Five Eyes member with the controversial TOLA Act allowing authorities to compel companies to build backdoors and assist in decryption.

national_laws.name: TOLA Act
national_laws.full_name: Telecommunications and Other Legislation Amendment (Assistance and Access) Act 2018
national_laws.summary: Can compel companies to build backdoors and assist in decryption, with secrecy requirements preventing disclosure.

name: Canada
description: Canada has an EU adequacy decision and PIPEDA provides reasonable data protection. However, as a Five Eyes member, there are intelligence-sharing concerns.

national_laws.name: PIPEDA
national_laws.full_name: Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act
national_laws.summary: Canadian federal privacy law for private sector organizations. Provides fair information principles.

name: Japan
description: Japan has an EU adequacy decision since 2019 and the APPI provides comprehensive data protection aligned with international standards.

national_laws.name: APPI
national_laws.full_name: Act on the Protection of Personal Information
national_laws.summary: Japanese data protection law, revised in 2020 to strengthen protections and align with GDPR.

name: South Korea
description: South Korea has an EU adequacy decision since 2022 and PIPA provides strong data protection with active enforcement.

national_laws.name: PIPA
national_laws.summary: Comprehensive Korean data protection law with strong enforcement and individual rights.

name: New Zealand
description: New Zealand has an EU adequacy decision and the Privacy Act 2020. However, as a Five Eyes member, there are intelligence-sharing considerations.

national_laws.name: Privacy Act 2020
national_laws.summary: Updated New Zealand privacy law with mandatory breach notification and strengthened enforcement.
